title: leo mckinstry schools reopening militant teaching unions
story: After the long summer holidays, it signies hope at the chance of fresh beginnings and excitement at the prospect of change.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNext week, the new term will have greater meaning than ever for pupils, professionals and parents. At last, after an unprecedented lockdown of six months, all schools are due to re-open, representing a giant leap back towards normality. But the damage caused by the Coronavirus disruption has been severe.Many parents have been prevented from ing to work. Young people’s education has been badly undermined, especially because the quality of online learning has been so uneven. One study found that a fth of pupils had less than an hour’s instruction a day. Moreover, social activities and friendships – which are a vital part of growing up – have been heavily restricted.The exam chaos over the last fortnight was a fitting symbol of the vacuum created by the absence of proper schooling. No advanced society canwhen a vital sector like education is temporarily paralysed. That is why it is so important that the Government succeeds in its goal of seeing a fullto the classroom. As Boris Johnson put it at the weekend, “it is vital for pupils’ education. It is vital for their welfare. It’s vital for their physical and, indeed, mental well-being.”Given the Government’s mixed record on its management of the Covid crisis, this will be a big test. From the inadequate supply of protective gear to the botched imposition of quarantine rules, Ministers have got it badly wrong at times. They cannot afford another fiasco next week.But to do that, they will have to curtail the influence of militant teaching unions, which thrive in a climate of scare-mongering and grievance. Full of negativity, these hardened left-wing operators turn every pebble of dficulty into a giant boulder of obstruction. They are the abominable no men and women, the ultimate “can’t do” brigade.To overcome the unions’ capacity for trouble-making, reassurances about safety will be absolutely crucial. Most teachers are keen to go back to work, but they want to know schools will not be dangerous environments. That is why the recent upbeat advice from medical experts has been so welcome. It is clear from the Covid experience around the world that not only are children less likely to transmit the disease than any other group, but also that schools are safer than most other workplaces. Yesterday, the Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries pointed out that a child is more likely to be involved in a traffic accident or die from flu than to be harmed by Coronavirus.That message was also spelt out by her boss Chris Whitty, who said on Sunday that the damage to health caused by a continued schools lockdown is potentially greater than the impact of Covid. “The balance of risk is very strongly in favour of children going to school,” he declared, adding the chances of catching the disease “are incredibly small.” In fact, there is now hard evidence to prove this. Although the vast majority of schools were closed since March, over one million pupils – such as the children of essential workers – went back to the classroom in June. Yet a comprehensive study by Public Health England showed that in the subsequent weeks until the end of term, just  children and  staff tested positive for Covid- – and nearly all these infections occurred outside the school. There were hardly any cases of children passing on the disease to each other, or to their teachers. Other research from around the world has come to the same conclusion.But none of this seems to matter to the teaching unions, eager to exploit anxiety in pursuit of their anti-Tory agenda. These are the organisations which for decades have blocked every major reform of the education system and have defended every outdated working practice. With depressing inevitability, they have continually put their own narrow interests before the wider needs of pupils. They want the respect due to trained professionals but they frequently display the rebellious spirit of the permanent agitators. “Strike action is a very powerful tool,” said Amanda Martin, the President of the ,-strong National Education Unionin an interview with the Communist Morning Star newspaper in , adding, “I’ve run demos and rallies and worked with trade councils to bring everyone out and that’s brilliant.”Led by the NEU, the unions have brought the same attitude to the Coronavirus crisis. Instead of looking for solutions, they have endlessly exaggerated problems. One Whitehall insider says of Dr Mary Bousted, the £,-a-year joint general secretary of the NEU, “it’s all about the union, to hell with the teachers who want to get back into the classroom – let alone the children.” A left-wing radical, Bousted jokes that the word “strike” was one of the first she learnt as a child. Hers is not the voice of co-operation and enterprise, so it is hardly surprising that the Government has struggled to get schools reopened.In June, a planned majorwas thwarted by the unions, dealing a severe blow to Gavin Williamson’s credibility. One left-wing website gushed that the continued shutdown was due “to the hard work of NEU branch secretaries and rank and file militants galvanising the members.” In the months since, an alliance of unions – including Bousted’s NEU and Unite led by the notorious Merseyside militant Len McCluskey – have fought a y battle against a swt re-opening. Central to this effort at sabotage was a vast -point checklist of detailed questions which the Department for Education was told it had to answer. Dubbed by critics “a wreckers’ charter”, the list included queries such as “will lidded bins with double bagging be available in every classroom”, “will dedicated space be available for any breastfeeding women to express milk” and “has behaviour policy been reviewed to acknowledge the increased level of trauma and anxiety experienced by pupils ” Some Tories complained that the union was playing politics. Robert Halfon, the chairman of the Education Select Committee was amazed at the warped priorities: “It is incredible that not one of these nit-picking questions asks the most important thing of all – what’s best for the kids ”Even as September approaches, the whining and resistance has not ceased. “The unions need to stand firm and protect their members,” argues socialist teacher Martin Powell-Davies. In the latest ruse, the public sector outfit UNISON not only wants its members to wear masks in the classroom – something for which there is no scientic evidence of any need – but also to have extra funding for deep cleaning. “Schools need more money to pay for specially trained cleaners, rather than relying on other staff who are busy enough already,” says Jon Richards, UNISON’s head of education. The moan about over-stretched budgets is a favourite of the union movement but it is an empty accusation. The Government is pouring an extra £. billion into education, while this summer it was announced that teachers’ pay is to go up by an average of . per cent, a bigger increase than any other public sector workers received.But that did nothing to stop the combination of whingeing and shroud-waving. The mentality of the hardliners was embodied in a recent statement from the NEU’s far left “Education Solidarity Network” which set out a series of demands to “make sure safety comes first.” Among them were: “smaller class sizes to allow adequate physical distancing” arrangements “for rotas and home learning to be produced in consultation with parents” “local risk assessments to include staggered outdoor breaks, sanitising, provision of transparent coverings to enable access to lip reading and facial expression” and “weekly onsite testing of staff”. Above all, the Network called for extra funding “to implement these measures.” If there were any question of a risk to safety, the union should “prepare for a national strike ballot.”That was so typical. This lot seem to feel more comfortable on the picket line than in the classroom. The Solidary Network might be seen as extreme, but its carping outlook runs right through the unionYesterday, the NEU’s joint general secretary was bleating on the airwaves about the risks of new Covid spikes: “Staff, parents and pupils are being sorely let down by the government because of a lack of a Plan B and of ensuring robust track and trace is in place throughout the country. We believe the Government is negligent in the extreme.” The charge of negligence might be applied with more force to the NEU, whose hostile stance has made thesuch an exhausting obstacle course. The militants cannot be allowed to prevail next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we need to return high street jane moore
story: Having sex was virtually impossible, because by the time we’d removed them we had fallen asleep with exhaustion.Now, jeans come in all shapes and sizes and — hallelujah — streeeeeeetch where necessary to accommodate our lumps and bumps.However, it’s imperative to try before you buyyou want to find the perfect pair and, thanks to lockdown, I found myself shopping for jeans, and other clothes — online.The results prove why we simply mustn’t allow our struggling High Street clothes shops to vanish without trace.I’m usually a size , but am now sporting a bread-baby after lock- down so decided to play safe by ordering a size bigger. Pictured is, apparently, a pair of “size ” jeans from online giant Asosin front of my old size sI couldn’t get them up one leg and, quite frankly, Kate Moss would struggle too. So they’re going back.Then a beguiling ad for summer dresses popped up on my Instagram account and I clicked through to a site called “Cinderear” showing a wide range of very pretty frocks on tanned and shapely models.I ordered what was described as a “Printed Folding Holiday Swing Dress” in what looked like an airy cotton, cinched in at the waist with a brown leather belt. The colour was described as apricot.What arrived — several weeks later — was a beyond-hideous sartorial aberration that was “Made in China” , out of a paper-thin polyester that would make me think twice about standing near a naked flame.What’s more, the colour was more camel and blue than “apricot”, it swamped me, and the brown belt in the photo was nowhere to be seen.It cost me  — approx £ — and the s policy is so ­unintelligible that it’s not worth the bother. More fool me.Buying a bookshelf or bog brush online is fine, but clothes is another matter. I like to feel the fabric and see the fit.So a couple of weeks ago, I masked up and ventured out on a shopping trip to West London’s vast Westfield where I felt like a ­Hollywood superstar having a ­personal shopping experience. It was am on a Monday morning and virtually empty.Little wonder when the ­government guidance says retailers must “discourage customers from handling products while browsing, and keep fitting rooms closed”.One store let me try on a dress then sanitised the cubicle afterwards, another told me thatI tried something on they would have to then take it off display for  hours.In LK Bennett, the fitting rooms were closed and I askedI could try on a blouse over my clothes, just to seeit actually fits. No, they said, you have to buy the item, take it home to try it on, then bring it backit doesn’t fit. Needless to say, I ed home empty-handed.So,our High Street clothes shops are to survive the pandemic, two things need to happen.Unless classed as vulnerable, those of us who actually enjoy clothes ­shopping need to get back out there as soon as possible and actively support them. And the Government needs to relax its strict rules and let retailers and shoppers take inidual responsibility for what happens in store.If I have to wear a mask and gloves to try on a pair of jeans in a cubicle, then I’m happy to do so. I’ll even wipe it down afterwards with my newly repurposed “apricot” dress.SPORTED by the likes of Chris Waddle back in the day, the mullet is apparently enjoying a resurgence during the pandemic.Oh dear. Now barbers have reopened, let’s hope the trend proves short-lived for the naff hairdo that was once described in a dictionary as: “Short at the front, long at the back and ridiculous all round.”FORMER Ukip leader Henry Bolton became embroiled in a scandal after leaving his third we for the charms of party supporter Jo Marney.Now, three years on, that relationship is also over. The reasons why are unclear, but Ms Marney, , says that aside from going on long walks and cosying up in country pubs, they “argued about the finer points of EU legislation”.Ah yes, that should do it.THE Duke and Duchess of Sussex will not feature in TV drama The Crown because there’s not “enough distance” from their story, says the show’s creator Peter Morgan.Also, their le is so outlandish that the series would fall under the category of reality show rather than drama.VINNIE JONES – the “hardman” of football – is seeing a psychologist three times a week after losing we Tanya to cancer.“I would recommend going to see a psychologist  per cent,” he says.“You’re not lying down on a couch asyou’re some lunatic or serial killer. Blokes don’t want to talk about it.“They’ll talk about the girl they slept with last night but won’t go and talk to a doctor about how they’re feeling.”He’s right, and with men accounting for  per cent of all suicides in the UK, it’s never been more important for men like Vinnie to convey that showing vulnerability isn’t a weakness – it’s an admirable strength.CLAUDIA SCHIFFER turned  on tuesday and says she has “never felt more confident or happy”.She adds that she embraces “now” and: “I don’t try to look or feel younger.”She doesn’t need to really, does she ELECTRIC car maker Tesla is developing a sensor that will detecta child has been left unattended in a hot car.Don’t we have those already They’re called parents.LIFE’S precious silences are few and far between. And when you’re PM, one can imagine they are practically non-existent.Particularly as, the ­second you step into the privacy of your own home, there’s a baby with no “on-off” switch.So Boris’s holiday tent – pitched a hundred yards away from his rented cottage on the Scottish coastline – intrigues me. Was it an escape for him alone to snatch a few hours of quiet reflection Or was it a chance for him and Carrie to have noisy sex away from the baby and ever-present bodyguards THE top dream jobs for school leavers are app or games developer and social media influencer.If kids don’t get back to school pronto, that’s all they’ll be able to do.NO ONE begrudges ­politicians a holiday – ­particularly during a ­parliamentary recess.But when you’re an Education minister, you have one job – to be around when the ordure inevitably hits the fan over A-level results being randomly downgraded by an algorithm.Yet not only did Gillian Keegan book a trip abroad, she actually posted a photo from the French Alps on results day – when countless students saw their future plans evaporate. Duh.She also decided to stay there after the quarantine rules came into force – meaning she will have to self-isolate at home for a fortnight on her .But hey ho she’s a taxpayer-funded civil servant so she’s comfortablein the knowledge that, unlike the self-employed, she won’t be losing any pay.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc does not represent britain
story: It is clear from its news, its commentary, its dramas and its dismal, lazy comedy that it despises the voting majority which — to the out-of-touch corporation’s disbelief — repeatedly backed both Brexit and the Tories.Its decision now to censor Rule, ­Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory ought to be the last straw.Boris Johnson has rightly joined many others in condemning it. And though it is not for the PM to decide the BBC’s output, his Government can and should end its publicly funded financial model.The Beeb could turn this around. It just doesn’t want to. It dislikes much about Britain and is ashamed of our past.Its woke staff are interested only in causes and ideas beloved of middle-class metropolitan Remainer graduates like them. Mainstream views shared by the ordinary majority, older Conservative voters in particular, are held in contemptthey are considered at all.So Tories, who won a huge election mandate only months ago, are treated with cynical disdain. Meanwhile ­left-wing activists are routinely given s on news programmes where they masquerade as “ordinary people” or even Newsnight journalists.The BBC has destroyed the case for its licence fee. It’s time the Government stopped griping about it and took action.THE U-turn on wearing Covid masks in schools is an own-goal.For months the Government, backed by its Sage scientists and a wealth of international evidence, assured parents it is entirely safe to start the new term.How so,kids in some areas now ­suddenly need masks — and Heads where will be able to bring them in too We don’t believe they are scientically necessary in schools at all, given how lightly the virus affects children and how rarely they spread it to teachers.All they will do is ramp up fear among pupils and over-anxious parents while causing teachers a discipline nightmare.And why the about-face, hours after denying masks would be needed in schools  Because Scotland brought them in  Because the WHO changed its tune  Because unions might have used their absence as a new wrecking tactic  None of those is a decent motive. Either the Government believes masks are medically essential in schools or, like its top advisers, it doesn’t. Which is it WHAT a superstar Jimmy Anderson is.His historic th Test wicket represents a mind-boggling feat unique among fast bowlers. For  years he has roared in for England. And he’s still fit as a fiddle.Howzat for a career GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rod liddle bbc rule britannia
story: All those ghastly people waving their Union Jacks. Singing Land of Hope and Glory and Rule, Britannia!. Nasty Little Englanders who probably voted for Brexit. It’s the one night of the year when the BBC’s left wing bias is dropped for an hour or two. And the licence-payer for once gets what they want. An evening of enjoyable, uplting patriotism.The BBC holds Middle England in utter contempt – and has done so for a long while. It cannot tolerate anything which doesn’t fit into its woke agenda. And it’s why support for the BBC diminishes daily. It has lost touch with the values of the people who pay for its existence.Still, there’s one bright side to all this. It’s saved me £. per year.I will not pay the licence fee any more. Not ever again. title: jacob blake riots hunt vigilante kyle rittenhouse kenosha
story: Kyle Rittenhouse, , was arrested after a gunman was filmed firing his AR--style rle at activists and brazenly walking past cops.The complaint stated that the teen says the teenager fled the state of Wisconsin with the intent to avoid prosecution for that offense.Two activists were killed during the alleged shooting spree, with one of the victims being named on social media as Anthony Huber, while a third man was shot in the arm.Wisconsin Attorney General Josh Kaul said: The violence and destruction that took place in Kenosha last night was despicable.While the two people who were killed and the person who was injured by gunfire have not yet been identied, we are thinking of their destroyed futures and their friends and families that must live with this overwhelming grief.Rittenhouses arrest came after:The Milmaukee Journal Sentinel noted that based on Wisconsin law, Rittenhouse is being charged as an adult.Rittenhouse was allegedly allowed to walk past a swarm of police with his hands up and holding his semi-automatic rle.The teen, from Antioch, Illinois, was today arrested and charged with first degree intentional homicide.Rittenhouse was interviewed before two activists were killed during the alleged shooting spree, with one of the victims being named on social media as Anthony Huber.He told a Daily Caller journalist people are getting injured as protesters decried the police shooting of Jacob Blake.The reporter noted that the business they stood outside of had been lit on fire the previous night as riots raged.Our job is protect this business, Rittenhouse said, standing outside of the boarded up building. And part of my job is to also help people.If theres somebody hurt, Im running into harms way and thats why I have my rle, to protect myself obviously.Protesters were heard screaming early this morning in Kenosha, Wisconsin as the shots were fired.Shocking footage shows a man being chased by demonstrators after he had already allegedly shot someone in the stomach a few blocks away, TMZ reported.The man in the video can be seen falling as hes chased before firing his gun, fatally hitting two people.As police arrive, the gun-slinging man they suspect to be Rittenhouse puts his hands up in the air and the cops pass him.The lead up to the fatal shooting isnt clear but police think it may have resulted from a gas station cojnflict.Cops said self-styled militias were defending local businesses from looters but the sherf didnt confirm that the gunman was one of the armed citizens patrolling the streets.Koerri Elijah told Insider that the teenager, later identied as Rittenhouse by cops, appeared to be on edge before he ran past him and shots rang out.I noticed him the entire time. He didnt seem like he was there with anyone, Elijah said. He was armed. He didnt seem like he was a threat, but I thought maybe I should keep an eye on him.Hours before he was identied as a suspect, social media sleuths named the teen boy and posted his picture online.Last night, the first shots were fired just after midnight, as a group of protesters faced off police in riot trucks on Sheridan Road.People were then seen chasing the man before another round of rapid-fire shots were heard.People on the streets were seen dragging the injured to the side of the road before performing CPR.After being shot in the head, a protester was loaded into the back of an SUV and rushed to a nearby hospital.Shocking pictures emerged of people tending to a wounded person during the vicious clashes.Other residents attempting to protect local businesses as fires raged throughout the city.Devin Scott, , told the Chicago Tribune he was in a group chanting Black Lives Matter when the gunfire began and that he tried unsuccessfully to revive one of the victims.He told the Tribune: This guy with this huge gun runs by us in the middle of the street and people are yelling, He shot someone! He shot someone!And everyone is trying to fight the guy, chasing him, and then he started shooting again.Scott said he hit the ground during the next burst of gunfire, then tried to aid a person who was lying prone in the street.He added: I was cradling him in my arms. I was trying to keep this kid alive and he wasnt moving or nothing. He was just laying there.Carol Badoni, from Burlington, Wisonsin, spoke to the girlfriend of one of the victims, she said his name was Ben Wis.Carol, , said: “He definitely was not breathing,”“His eyes were rolled back in his head. There was no pulse.”But she added that she saw no blood, before cops arrived and took Ben to hospital.In another clip, a man was seen removing his top to help another victim of the shooting.Meanwhile, other protests erupted across the country in response to the shooting.Police in Portland, Oregon, also declared a gathering of hundreds of anti-racism protesters outside City Hall as a riot, ordering the crowd to disperse or face arrest.People at the Kenosha protest were heard shouting: Theres people getting shot everywhere.Kenosha has been riddled with violence, looting, criminal damage and fires in response to the death of Jacob Blake, a -year-old black man who was shot by police.Blake was shot several times in the back by police as he stepped into his car.His horried children were in the car at the time and would have seen the attack.On Tuesday, Blakes family confirmed that he is still alive but in a critical condition and is paralyzed.Jacob Blake Sr. said: They shot my son seven times. Seven times. Like he didnt matter. But my son matters. Hes a human being and he matters.While his family have pleaded for peaceful protests, they have hit out at police, saying they systematically brutalize black peoplePolice attempted to boarder off Kenosha after Monday nights protests led to buildings being set on fire and stores looted.Seven exit ramps were closed from Interstate- from the Illinois border to Racine, Wis. which is about  minutes north of Kenosha.In downtown Kenosha, a huge crowd of protesters gathered around the barrier at Kenosha County Courthouse.One protester, Nathan, , who didnt want to give his full name said: A lot of fear in the air because of threats to protesters.“I worry a lot about the misinformation,” he said after explaining he didnt think national movement to bring greater police accountability will lead to real change.Although, he said locally, his city will never be the same.“It’s hard to see now, but it will be a positive thing,” he said of the protests.“It’ll bring Kenosha back together. Kenosha has always been a resilient place. It’ll continue to happen.”Thousands joined the protest on Tuesday, with some carrying handguns, AR- rles, knives and dressed in military flak jackets.Dennis, , from Racine, was carrying a pistol he claimed was for protection for himself and other protesters.“Nothing is going to change,” he said, hanging back from the crowd. “This is all for nothing.”A group of the protesters began violently shaking the barriers and launched fireworks at the police officers.Cops were seen firing tear gas pellets and rubber bullets into the crowd.One officer was heard shouting: Yall better have gas masks on! Get ready!Before another cop was seen opening the hatch of the vehicle and throwing the canister in their direction.Another man was heard shouting: F**king p**sies!By pm  policwe officers dressed in riot gear formed a chain across the park nearby the court house.There were  fires associated with the unrest, with  businesses destroyed or damaged along with an unknown number of residences, Kenosha Fire Chief Charles Leipzig told the Kenosha News.On Tuesday, President Donald Trump urged Wisconsin officials to call in the National Guard to quell the unrest, despite troops already being on the ground.Governor should call in the National Guard in Wisconsin. It is ready, willing, and more than able. End problem FAST! Trump tweeted.On Monday, residents with firearms were seen standing outside local businesses in a bid to stop the looting and arson.One of the armed men in the footage taken Monday night says: Theyre destroying their own neighborhood. Its not the civilians.Go f*** up the government that just killed your man. Dont f*** up your neighbors. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: grandpa teeth pliers
story: Machine operator Phil Bailey has worked on building sites up and down the country so never registered with a local dentist.Whenever the grandads tooth starts to hurt or cause him pain, he just asks a colleague to tear it out.The -year-olds unconventional dental procedures have been caught many times on camera. Most recently, Phil took matters into his own hands on Monday when he handed a fellow builder a pair of pliers to tackle his aching molar.In the footage, Phil, from Castleford, West Yorks., then opens his mouth wide as his colleague then rips his tooth out of his gum with one hard pull. Phil doesnt even make a sound as he shows the freshly-removed tooth up to the camera.The widower has always had his teeth pulled on site but has only asked for the bizarre moments to be filmed in the last few years.Phil said: If a tooth starts hurting me, I’ll just wait until Im on site and ask one of the lads to yank it out. I always ask them to film.This tooth had been giving me jip over the weekend so when I got in on Monday morning, I just asked one of the lads to grab some pliers and pull it out.I dont really have many problems with my teeth these days, because there arent that many left.I have got a very high pain threshold. If you have a day off work to get your teeth pulled you can miss out on a days pay or in the past you might lose your job.Ive never been registered with a dentist. title: tories wore frank spencer benny crossroads
story: A magnicent record to behold. I cannot remember any government being so devoid of direction, leadership, policy, conviction and — frankly — intelligence.And I had to endure Ted Heath AND John Major’s attempts to run the country. Oh, and the shaft of glorious sunshine that was Gordon Brown. Those guys have nothing on Boris. He is the clear leader in the field. If you ever wanted to know what a country would look likeit was led by Frank Spencer, here you go. Yes, I know — I’m showing my age. To be honest, under this administration I’m feeling my age.For those who don’t remember, Frank was a bumbling, dithering, halfwit from the s sitcom Some Mothers Do ’Ave ’Em. The only dference with Bojo is that Frank was thinner. And, mercully, a fictional creation. Boris is all too real. Many kids will be going back to school wearing face masks. For ages, this government insisted that they would not have to do so. Now they’ve changed their minds. Face masks and grouped in “bubbles”. Probably getting only about half of their usual education,that. Any kid who coughs will be pounced upon, exiled to the Outer Hebrides and the entire school shuts down. Never mind that there has been no recorded case of a schoolkid passing on the virus to a teacher.Never mind that our economy needs the schools fully open with a proper, normal, timetable, so people can get back to work.After six months of no lessons , the kids now have to endure insufferable conditions at school.This is because Boris and the rest have proved utterly incapable of standing up to the teaching unions .Other U-turns have involved the wearing of masks in shops, the usefulness of masks in general, whether there’s any point in closing our borders, the schools due to re-open in June, the scrapping of an expensive track and trace system, the re-grading of GCSEs and A levels . . . oh lordy, the list goes on and on.Sometimes the U-turn appears only a day after the original decision.Sometimes we have to wait a week or so. But come they surely do, a long parade of staggering ineptitude. In fact, I think even Frank Spencer would have been more decisive. Maybe the right comparison is with Benny from Crossroads. Yes, it’s my age again. For those who don’t know, Benny was a cast-iron moron.We know that dealing with this horrible pandemic can’t have been easy. We know Boris has had a dficult year.But the utter lack of planning and resolve has been astonishing. Slow to take the virus seriously, bizarrely refusing to close our airports at the peak of the outbreak, hopelessly lost over track and trace and what do with our poor kids.This has been mismanagement on an almost heroic level. My guess is that Boris will not survive as Prime Minister: His party will get shot of him when the opportunity arises. Because here’s the crucial, damaging question.Could Jeremy Corbyn have handled this crisis any worse I DON’T think those smug monkeys at the BBC realised the fury they would unleash when they banned singing our favourite anthems at The Last Night Of The Proms.A petition reached , names in just  hours.And Dame Vera Lynn is suddenly at No in the iTunes chart with Land Of Hope And Glory.The BBC apparently agreed with the Finnish conductor, Dalia Stasevska, that the “jingoistic” words of Land Of Hope And Glory and Rule Britannia would not be heard this year.I wonder what convinced Ms Stasevska to agree to conduct an evening of patriotic songs when she hates patriotic songs Money, you would guess. Meanwhile another BBC bureaucrat, Cat Lewis, likened singing the songs to Nazis singing about gas chambers.Silly woman. The BBC – its entire staff – has no understanding of the British people. It despises them. Support for the corporation is at an all-time low. And yet the BBC is still up to its tricks. Pulling off the unusual feat of being already in a coffin, but reaching out somehow to hammer more nails into its own lid.A TEAM of British scientists has been studying dreams and what they mean.And they’ve discovered they mean sod all. They are just a continuation of memories from the previous day.Other recent studies showed the same thing. So,you dream you’re flying around your house with some bats, it means you were probably thinking about bats when you were awake.It doesn’t mean you’re neurotic or sexually repressed. So – that’s all the work of Sigmund Freud in the bin. It can go in a black bin liner along with the idiocies put forward by that other drongo of the th Century, Karl Marx. But given that we know all this, why are there still psychoanalysts plying their trade  Is it just to give Britain’s couch-makers plenty of work ANOTHER stupid, virtue-signalling British firm has run into trouble.Avanti West Coast made a big fuss about its new “pride train”, which runs from London to Manchester.The engine is painted in the colours of the LGBT rainbow flag.And it has the word “Pride” written in big letters – just in case anyone doesn’t get the message. There have been thousands of angry comments on social media.My favourite was from John James McGivern: “As a gay man, I don’t want a ‘pride train’, I just want to get on a train that runs on time like everyone .” Quite. Well said.Every time companies pull a stunt like this, the nation cringes.I don’t want a bloody voucher. You cancel the train I’m booked on, then refund the ticket.So I complain to them and they say nothing we can do.So I complain some more and tell them they’re acting illegally.Bingo – money back! I know a lot of people have had similar problems with airlines cancelling their flights and offering “vouchers”.It pays to pester these buggers. Pester and pester until they give in.POOR old slabhead, then. title: ex education chiefs call to reopen schools
story: Tories Damian Hinds, Justine Greening and Kenneth Baker, Labour’s David Blunkett and Lib Dem David Laws all united.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThey told The Sun there is a “desperate need” to reopen schools and they warned: “The future of our country depends on it.” Any longer out of the classroom risks causing untold damage to kids’ studies, health and wellbeing, they added.Together, their time in charge of England’s schools spanned four decades.Ex-Education Secretary Lord Blunkett, , said: “Getting schools reopened is absolutely fundamental to everything that we stand for.“We send children to school for a purpose — and that is because their very future and the future of our ­country depends on it.”The country’s schools, colleges and nurseries closed for most kids in March as coronavirus swept the country.The national schools shutdown was the first in English history and a string of alarming reports found it has ­massively widened the education gap between rich and poor. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has promised to get all of England’s pupils back to class full- time next week.The ex-schools supremos warned that No cannot fail in this test.Lord Baker,  — who was Education Secretary under Margaret Thatcher — said that the Covid education crisis could be as bad as the recession.He said: “This is the Prime Minister’s biggest challenge now, getting all children back to school.“You will find that some parents are anxious, and that some children won’t want to go back — but we have got to get them into the routine of schools.“Once you lose out on a stage of your schooling like this, you may end up losing out for ever.“It affects a child’s entire future. It is very, very important and it must happen.” Ms Greening, , who was Education Secretary under Theresa May, said the past six months have been “hugely damaging” for kids.She said: “Parents have done their level best home-schooling but we urgently need schools open safely so children can get back to full-time education. We also need a catch-up plan to help them recover lost ground.”Mr Hinds, , Education Secretary until July last year, said: “Kids desperately need to get back to school.“In the immediate term, mental and physical health are supported by the routine of going to school, interacting with friends and teachers and accessing purposeful activity.”Mr Laws, , Schools Minister during the Coalition, said: “Given the huge learning loss during lockdown, particularly for the poorest children, it’s vital we do everything we can to ensure a fullto school next week, provided this is supported by the health advice.”It is a crucial test for Education Secretary Gavin Williamson, who is clinging on to his job by a thread in the wake of humiliating U-turns on mask wearing in schools and A-level results.Fuming Tory MPs have urged No to sack himhe fails to get schools reopened on time.Perhaps an adult wearing a mask in a lab makes them safer but I believe children in a school will be less safe with masks. Do we really imagine a world where our teenagers turn up every day to school with a freshly washed mask which they will wear without issue throughout the day  They will swap their masks, ping them, lick them, spit in them and pass them around for fun. They will shout obscenities through them, bully each other over not having the right type, wear them wrong and they will encourage them to touch their faces dozens of times a day.And teachers need to be able to see the mouths of their charges to hold them to account for chatting, swearing and the like. Mask them up and teachers won’t have a clue who said it. Eventually you have chaos in the classroom. Hand-washing, social-distancing as much as one can and keeping children in bubbles is the way to go. Headteachers should not be swayed by how things appear and rather look seriously at how things really are.Schools in Wales are also reopening next week, while they have been open for a fortnight already in Scotland.All of the UK’s chief medical officers have declared that it is safe for children toto school.On a visit to a school in Leicestershire today, Mr Johnson said: “This is an absolutely invaluable time for them — they must get back into school.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. This shouldnapost be necessary to say, because we all had history lessons and we were awake for some of them. But Britannia has never ruled the waves.We had officially-approved pirates who stole gold from the Spanish and started the slave trade. We had glorious navies that had a habit of sinking, we dodged U-boats, we provided the first circumnavigation of the globe, and the first man to do it alone. But we also had a king who told the waves to go away, and collective amnesia about the point he was trying to make.King Cnut did not get his feet wet in the th century just so he could be a cipher for a swearword on Twitter , years later. He tried to rule the waves in order to prove that, despite being a warrior king with  North Sea countries beneath his heel, waves do their own thing. Britannia was around before him, was revived as a bit of Elizabethan militarist propaganda, and in  got nicked by a prince who wanted a song to impress his dad, George II. At the time, our ruling of the waves was centred on what became known as the War of Jenkinsapos Ear, about slave trading rights. We lost. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Government performed another spectacular and humiliating U-turn last night, this time on children wearing masks or face coverings in English schools. Ministers had insisted there would be no recommendation for children to wear face coverings in communal areas, and said the scientic evidence backed them up. But late last night, after the Scottish Government had issued obligatory guidance that pupils should wear face coverings when moving around schools from Monday, the Department for Education issued a change in advice. But what are the new rules  When and where will children have to wear masks - and will it apply to all schools  Hereaposs everything you need to know about the new changes. What measures are being introduced in England  From September , and in secondary schools in England that are within areas under local restrictions, face coverings should be worn when moving around corridors and communal spaces. This does not include classrooms and does not apply to primary-aged pupils. Why are face coverings not required in classrooms   Guidance from the Department for Educationsays that it will not usually be necessary in classrooms, as protective measures mean the risks are lower - such as grouping staff and students in bubbles. Face coverings can have a negative impact on learning and teaching and so their use in lessons should be avoided, it adds.So in which areas should face coverings be worn in secondary schools  Additional precautionary measures apply to places defined as areas of national Government intervention, as listed on the gov.uk website, according to the guidance. Local restrictions are currently in place in areas of Greater Manchester, Lancashire, and West Yorkshire, Leicester, Luton and Northampton. Can schools recommend face coveringsthey are where in England  Schools and colleges outside of local lockdown areas will have the discretion to require face coverings in communal areas where social distancing cannot be safely managed, the guidance says. It gives the example of a school or college which has a layout that makes it particularly dficult for people to stay apart. Are there any exemptions  Yes. Those who cannot put on, wear or remove a face covering because of a physical or mental illness or impairment, or disability, will be exempt. Guidance says that exemptions also apply to people who provide assistance to someone who relies on lip-reading, clear sound or facial expression to communicate. Could the measures be changed further  Education Secretary Gavin Williamson ruled out the requirements for face coverings in Englandaposs schools being extended further. When askedthe measures could be extended, he told the BBC: No, no, thereaposs no intention of extending it beyond that because as bothsaid andsaid is that actually that isnapost what is required. What has the Scottish Government announced on face coverings  Face coverings should be worn by staff and pupils when moving around secondary schools in Scotland from August , according to Holyroodaposs Education Secretary. John Swinney said that the rule will apply on school transport for primary school pupils aged five and above, and all those at secondary school in communal areas, but not in classrooms.

Michelle Tomlinson turned to the media after she and husband Ashley were separated when he flew to Yorkshire from Australia to be by his dying dadaposs bedside - and was told he could not fly back.It was only after reporters from Australiaaposs News had contacted the Australian Border Forcethat Ashley was given an exemption - but Michelle had already resigned from work and packed up their Perth home ready to leave for the UK to be reunited with her husband.Ashley flew to the UK to say goodbye to his dying dad Owen in March - just as Australia closed its borders to all but citizens and permanent residents. His dad died from cancer a week later. Nurse Michelle and prison officer Ashley have lived in Australia for almost eight years on a skilled visa, News reports. This meant he was barred from reentering the country, but Ashley was hopeful he would be allowed back home. Ashley booked a flight the day after the announcement but he was not allowed to fly. He put his first appeal for a travel exemption in as he sat at Manchester Airport waiting for his flight. In all, the couple has had seven applications to the ABF rejected. Michelle was set to fly out to Yorkshire yesterday, and said she felt they had been treated cruelly by the Australian government. She told news: I feel really let down. We have lived here coming up to eight years. We have paid our taxes. We have both been working full time. We have contributed to the Australian economy, and nobody seems to care. Itaposs almost like youaposre not permanent residents so you donapost matter. But after the Australian media site approached the ABF for comment, Michelle received a notication hours later from the Department of Home Affairs that Ashleyaposs travel exemption had been approved.  Michelle said the couple have been left in absolute turmoil...somewhere between angry and destroyed right now. The exemption seems to have come to late, and Michelle claims to have spent , shipping belongings to the UK and buying flights for herself, two dogs and three cats. Michelle said the trauma could have been avoidedthe exemption had been granted a fortnight earlier - and suspects the authorities did not make the decision out of compassion, but for fear of bad press. Workers’ leaders representing . million staff warned they were being “fobbed off” by the Treasury, which left many health service employees out of a recent wage-hike announcement. However, she contracted the virus and was ill for five weeks.  Although Daniella avoided being admitted to hospital, she still bears the physical and mental scars of the disease. Despite suffering pain and breathlessness, she has ed to work. But the virus has left her too vulnerable to go back to her frontline role and she now helps staff who had been shielding toto work. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Queen’s favourite sporting event - Royal Ascot - is considering axing Rule, Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory from its world famous bandstand celebrations next year.For more than  years the tradition of singing around the bandstand sees hundreds of racegoers form a joyous choir to celebrate the end of each day at Royal Ascot.The custom was formed by the late Lady Jinny Beaumont, the we of Sir Nicky Beaumont, Clerk of the Course from  to , with punters singing a collection of popular numbers including Hey Jude, Sweet Caroline and Tom Jones’ smash hit Delilah. The performance, belted out by singer John Park for the last  years, ends in rousing renditions of English favourite Jerusalem, Rule, Britannia!, Land of Hope and Glory and a spirited finale of God Save the Queen. The pm event on each day of the five-day Berkshire festival has become synonymous with Royal Ascot. Her Majesty attends each day with huge sums being placed on the colour of hat as more than , racegoers pack into the course over the festival.This year’s meeting was cancelled due to the coronavirus crisis with the Queen tuning in from isolation at Windsor Castle.Now festival organisers have confirmed they will potentially scrap the controversial songs from the bandstand setlist, in light of the furore over their inclusion in the upcoming Last Night of the Proms Festival in light of the Black Lives Matter Movement. Campaigners have argued the songs should be fazed out of their perceived association with colonialism and slavery after the BBC announced it would play an instrumental version at the Last Night Of The Proms next month.  There will be no live audience to sing along and wave flags at the September  concert because of coronavirus restrictions. One well placed racing insider said: “Much like the move to remove Rule Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory from the Royal Albert Hall festival, there is a rising level of unease among the organisers who are certainly fearing a backlash because of those particular songs’ perceived association with colonialism and slavery. “Despite all the traditions of the past, the feeling at the moment is that it would be most unwelcome attention for the festival, the Queen and the rest of the royal family and a decision to remove the singalong is expected to be ratied.” A spokesperson for Royal Ascot said on Wednesday: “The pieces selected for the meeting are a mixture of traditional and more modern songs.  “As in previous years, these will be reviewed in the run up to Royal Ascot.” One option on the table is to ban Mr Park from singing the two songs but to allow the band to play the music. Our source said: “Most people don’t know the words anyway so it was muted that there would potentially be no singing, although they are particularly rousing numbers which does add to occasion.”Prime Minister Boris Johnson yesterdayagain waded into the controversial row, amid heated debate over the songs’ historical meanings. During a visit to Castle Rock School in Coalville, Leicestershire, he insisted it is politically acceptable to sing Rule Britannia! Meanwhile, Andrew Lloyd Webber has suggested his collaborator Sir Tim Rice could “fix the offending couplet” in Rule, Britannia! as the row over the Last Night Of The Proms rumbled on. New, orchestral versions of Rule, Britannia! and Land Of Hope And Glory will be performed on the final night of the Proms this year, but Lord Lloyd-Webber said the anthem will sound “ordinary at best” without lyrics. The outgoing director-general of the BBC, Lord Tony Hall, has said the decision to remove the lyrics was a “creative” one, but confirmed that the issue of dropping songs because of their association with Britain’s imperial history had been discussed.

It is a shame the Prime Minister did not find the time to talk to the parents of the pupils during his visit. He then would have heard first-hand their frustration and dismay over the confused guidance on reopening schools next week. Parents, teachers and unions are crying out for clarity. Instead they have been given conflicting advice, not least on face masks. Earlier this week ministers were adamant there was no need for secondary school pupils in England to wear face coverings. Now they are being told they have to wear them in certain circumstances. This farce comes just days after the exam gradings fiasco. Little wonder that many parents have concluded the Government is making up policy as it goes along. The Prime Minister should spend less time posing for the cameras and more time addressing their concerns. MP class snub Two years ago a report found that bullying and sexual harassment was a signicant problem in Westminster. At the time we were promised a change in the culture at Parliament.  Key to that was MPs attending anti-sexual harassment training. But so far,  Conservative MPs have failed to take the course. This includes the Prime Minister and  other Cabinet ministers.

title: tribe dig up loved ones
story: NewsTribe dig up loved ones’ corpses and light cigarettes for them in annual traditionThe Toraja community of Indonesia have engaged in the annual Ma’nene ritual, which sees them spend time with the corpses of dead relatives, who they shower with gts before placing back in their cleaned tombsShareCommentsByJoseph WilkesReporter:,  AUG NewsFamily members give cigarettes to the preserved body of their relative. Roni Pasang - centre - hugs his dead cousin " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAstonishing images have emerged of an annual ritual where villagers dig up the bodies of their dead relatives. The Toroja community of Indonesia pull their dead relativesapos corpses from their tombs, clean and clothe them before spending time with them, chatting and lighting cigarettes for them. Itaposs an annual tradition and happens every August before planting season in the community in Panggala, Nort Toraja, South Sulawesi, but the photos never fail to astound. The annual Toraja death rituals - or Ma’nene ritual - are inspired by the communityaposs belief in an infinite link between le and death. This year, two men are pictured with the mummied corpse of a dead relative, who has had a baseball cap stuck on his head and a cigarette in his mouth, which the men are lighting. The tribe consider the ritual a celebration of le and an act which honours the spirits of their ancestors. They interact with the mummied corpses asthey were alive, and clean their graves and replace decorated coffins before putting them back. The whole act is seen as something of a second funeral and steps are taken to prevent the bodies from decomposing. They are usually reentered with gts in their colourful coffins. And in the modern era, tribespeople use their smartphones to take pictures with their dead relatives.  In one picture, community member Roni Pasang hugs the corpse of his dead cousin. Families often keep the mummied corpses of the recently deceased in their homes for months - sometimes years - as they mourn and prepare and save money for the burial, which they find hugely signicant. Sometimes they use a ‘Tongkonan’ - a building specically designed to house the dead before burial.  The Torajans often get into crippling debt from funerals, as they place so much importance on death as the most important aspect of le. The dead are interacted with asthey are alive, often being included in family meals. In one image, the corpse of a little girl is seen newly clothed in a purple dress, shoes, a hair band and even a wig while Lin Arensia poses with her.  In a later picture, Lin takes a selfie with grandfather Ne Potta. The dead relatives are laid in their tomb in the fresh clothes, and every year knives are used to cut them away so it can be replaced. One picture shows a pair of Adidas shoes being placed on a relativeaposs foot.  Another corpse is given a new hat, sunglasses, shorts and a watch. Sticks are used to hold them up and the corpses are cleaned with dry paint brushes. Conversely, the Toraja people are a largely Protestant Christian community, living in a country where the majority of the population are Muslim.  But the annual tradition remains entrenched in their culture down the centuries. For Torajans, the death of the body isn’t seen as an abrupt event and attempts are made to keep them part of the family. According to their ancient belief system, the spirit of a dead person mustto his village of origin.  Soa person died on a journey, the dead person would be walked back home from the scene to the village. Torajan Eric Crystal Rante Allo last year told The Sydney Morning Herald: Toraja people believe the spirit of the dead lives among us, the living, looking out for us, blessing us. That’s why, before the ritual of the burial is performed, they are called to’makula, or just sick, not yet dead. Toraja’s people highly respect their dead.  Now Bartolomeus, a rice farmer, said: It’s like when you come home for Christmas, it’s that feeling of joy meeting someone you haven’t seen for a long time. A lot of people would consider a graveyard a scary place.

title: eight north east towns receive financial support from covid 19 fund
story: Eight north-east towns have been awarded more than £, to help communities recover from the impact of Covid-.The money has come from The Towns and Business Improvement DistrictsResilience and Recovery Fund, financed by the Scottish Government and administered by Scotland’s Towns Partnership.Nearly  towns across Scotland have benefited from £m of grants including Aboyne, Ballater, Banchory, Ellon, Huntly, Mintlaw, Stonehaven and Turrf.In total, the fund has supported  projects –  in full and  in part – covering  inidual towns. Money has been granted to organisations including local authorities and community business groups.Aberdeenshire organisations which received a grant including Huntly and Stonehaven business associations which received support for an Our Community Hub App and Shop Local campaigns. Other towns will be using the money to introduce marketing campaigns, events and loyalty card schemes.Phil Prentice, chief officer of Scotland’s Towns Partnership, said: #Businesses in our town centres are showing remarkable resilience and innovation in how they are responding to the consequences of Covid- to best serve their customers and communities.#From rapidly accelerating their online offerings to moving quickly to ensure that safeguards are in place to ensure that staff can work safely and customers shop responsibly, their work is playing an important part in the nation’s recovery from the pandemic.#The impact they are having should not be underestimated. We are delighted to have been able to support the projects we have and pleased that the work will touch on so many towns as we encourage everyone to think local first # and safety first # to support the businesses and the people behind them who really are at the heart of the areas in which they live.#Audrey Michie, strategic town centre executive at Aberdeenshire Council, said: #It’s great to see our local business groups and community organisations developing schemes to protect people as theyto our retail and hospitality sectors.#Thanks to their efforts, our local town centres are safe and will get the much-needed boost they deserve after months of financial uncertainty.#By supporting local shops, cafes, restaurants and other services within your own community, you are directly supporting local jobs which has never been so important.#For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: mp praises staff on visit to north east health centre
story: A north-east MP has congratulated health centre staff on the way they have dealt with the Covid- pandemic.Douglas Ross, the MP for Moray, visited a practice in his constituency to find out about how they had coped with the crisis and their plans going forward.While visiting Moray Coast Medical Centre, the recently-appointed Scottish Conservative leader paid tribute to the way staff had dealt with the challenge.He said: “It was really interesting to have a tour of the surgery and hear from the staff about how the Covid restrictions resulted in a complete change in the way they work. I know that all the medical practices in Moray have had to adapt to these unprecedented times and I want to thank everyone involved for ensuring that patients have continued to have access to medical services and advice.“During my visit to the Moray Coast practice, they explained how  per cent of consultations are now done by phone, covering patients registered at Lossiemouth, Hopeman and Burghead, with the addition of online video so that a ‘face-to-face’ consultation can take place where necessary.“I am so impressed by the dedication shown by the whole team at Moray Coast Medical Centre and it was great to be able to thank them for all the work they are doing to ensure that local people can still have access to the surgery, albeit in a dferent way.“We are lucky in Moray that everyone working in GP surgeries in our towns and villages have adapted to the immense challenges that Covid- has presented and that patients are still being provided with fantastic care.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: letters to the editor july 17 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe following letter appeared in the Argyllshire Advertiser#s sister title, the Campbeltown Courier, last week, with the reply sent since publication of Mr Redman#s letter.Sir,The SNP is failing councils, as recent figures show that the cost of coronavirus to local authorities could hit more than £ million.Under the SNP essential local services have been underfunded for years, yet it is councils that are spearheading the response to this virus. Without action and proper investment from central government vital public services will be at risk.This news of huge strain on local authority budgets comes as the SNP is delaying in opening up Scotland’s hospitality and tourism industry. Instead of following other parts of the UK and opening the sector on July , the separatists are forcing businesses to wait until July .This delay will cost businesses millions at a time when thousands of jobs are already on the line.The SNP is risking people#s livelihoods. It needs to accept responsibility for that and take action now.Councillor Alastair Redman,Sir,People occasionally ignore the elephant in the room to support their point of view, but in his latest letter, Councillor Alastair Redman has ignored an entire herd in his living room.In his latest rant he states that the SNP is failing councils as the cost of coronavirus could hit more than £ million, but surely these costs would be the same no matter who was in power He also suggests that #essential local services have been underfunded for years# yet fails to mention the years of needless austerity cuts, actioned by his party and their collaborators, to bail out the greedy and risky practices of the banks, which reduced funding to a devastatingly low level in general. It is worth noting that the Scottish Government has put a greater percentage of their curtailed income into NHS Scotland than any part part of the UK. This has helped NHS Scotland to outperform all of the others, in the UK, for the past five years. This is paying idends now.He s to his familiar attempt to insult by referring to citizens who want to take responsibility for making and managing decisions and working to make their country prosper within the priorities set by its citizens as #separatists#. I’m glad to be described as a separatist because the alternative is to be an apologist for an unrepresentative government in Westminster and to abdicate decision making to that same out-of-touch group.It is Councillor Redman’s final point, however, that demonstrates his blinkered sycophancy. His suggestion that the Scottish Government should follow the example of other parts of the UK. Could he really be saying that we should follow the chaotic shambles and incompetence that has emanated from his chums at Westminster  Does he seriously think that any sensible person, irrespective of their own political affiliation and from any of the devolved nations, would swap what their government#s have done for the Westminster model Sadly, nowhere in his missive does Councillor Redman take time to mention the health and safety of our citizens.It is this, together with scientic advice and without political point scoring, that is driving the Scottish Government#s response to this tragic pandemic.Kevin MacKaveney, TarbertSir,Following reports of littering around Argyll and Bute, including the Isle of Islay, the issue was discussed at a recent meeting of Islay Community Council where community councillors heard that items like rubber gloves have been found dumped in ditches.It is always very disappointing to hear about littering and fly-tipping but doubly so in an area like Islay where residents take such an understandable pride in their environment.We also need to bear in mind that items like disposable gloves can pose a threat to livestock. As well as being profoundly antisocial, this kind of behaviour can be positively harmful.Those acting irresponsibly should remember that there can be serious consequences to their thoughtlessness.Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands MSPSir,We all have a role to play in the recovery of the country’s tourism industry after its reopening on July .Scots could help by taking a trip, visiting an attraction or experience, shopping locally, dining out and booking a staycation.Scottish tourism is facing its biggest challenge in a generation and will need financial support for some time to come to help it recover. The Scottish public has a crucial part to play in helping this happen.It#s easy to not think of yourself as a tourist in your own country but many of the experiences that we often enjoy with loved ones, such as holidays, shopping or eating out, all contribute to our visitor economy.July  marked a new era for the industry as we start to welcome back visitors and take our first steps on the road to a safe and responsible recovery. However, reopening won’t be the same for all businesses, many are still adapting to this #new normal#, so it#s important that we recognise that as we move forward to try and restore our industry.We look forward to helping Scots rediscover their own country in a way that is safe for everyone # visitors, residents and those working within the industry. Recovery will require our collective efforts and we must act as one to ensure the best possible outcomes for the whole of the visitor economy.Malcolm Roughead, VisitScotland chief executive

title: the time for change is is now july 17 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThis isn’t really a campaign, it’s just the things that we should all be thinking aboutwe want Argyll # and the world – to be a recognisable place for our children and grandchildren to live in.The economic crisis could be seen as an opportunity to get started on the work that we know needs to happen.I think that many people in Argyll could continue to work from home people who have lost their jobs could be retrained, or use their existing skills, to do the work that is necessary for Argyll to become carbon-neutral. Walking and cycling infrastructure needs to be improved, trees can be planted, and renewable energy can be expanded and made more efficient.Transport and food are the most obvious areas for behavioural change in Argyll. We need to be promoting the benefits of electric cars and making them preferable to petrol or diesel cars.We can easily bring food production and consumption closer together by shopping and eating more locally and more naturally. Farming in Argyll is generally quite low impact, but does not have the capacity to feed everyone in the area, meaning that we have to buy in meat which is less sustainably farmed to make up the dference. If everyone ate only the meat that is produced locally, we could dramatically reduce the emissions caused from the transport of imported meat, as well as supporting our local market and ensuring that it remains natural and sustainable. Reducing food waste is also an easy behavioural change.Acting on climate change is all about thinking of others. Across the globe, the people who see the most adverse effects of climate change so far are those who are already marginalised and vulnerable.Kindness and common decency indicate that we must act with the needs of these people in mind, with the knowledge thatwe do not act, ‘these people’ will soon become us and our children.One thing that I think would make a huge dference would bewe all took #our whole selves# to work with us.Whatworld leaders were constantly thinking: #what would my children say about my role in this decision # This kind of moral thinking would make a huge dference in the future of industry and politics, and the more we educate the next generation, the more influence they will have on their parents.Everyone can make changes such as cutting down on their meat and dairy consumption, shopping locally, re-using plastic containers, recycling, composting, reducing food waste, buying fewer new things, using a renewable energy supplier, and cutting down or cutting out air travel.At the Paris Agreement in ,  nations decided to take measures to limit the global temperature increase to . degrees above pre-industrial levels. Our current behaviour will not allow for this.A rise of  degrees celsius above pre-industrial levels will mean that large areas of land around the equator will be uninhabitable, resulting in huge numbers of refugees fleeing for their survival. Sea level rise caused by the rapid melting of the ice caps will mean that small island states such as Kiribati and Tuvalu will be submerged. The combination of the loss of arable land and ocean acidication due to temperature increase will mean global food shortages, such that we have never seen before.The rich will still be able to buy food, but those who are already marginalised and vulnerable will find it increasingly dficult to access basic amenities like food and clean water, further stretching the inequality gap.It’s not too late to make changes, but it soon will be.We all need to have climate change in the forefront of our minds when making any kind of decision, be it personal or business. It is an omnipresent issue and every decision, however big or small, will have an effect.

title: science matters are aircraft vapour trails harmful
story: Dorothy H CrawfordUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsAlthough much reduced by the Coronavirus pandemic, everyone has seen the vapour trails produced by high-flying aircraft as they streak across the sky. But what are they  and are they harmful Officially called contrails , these ephemeral, cloud-like structures are primarily made of ice crystals. They form at altitudes over , metres from water vapour in the aircraft’s engine exhaust as it freezes almost instantaneously at temperatures below minus  degrees celsius. There are, however, plenty of other volatiles and solid components in engine exhaust, including soot particles that often act as a nucleus around which the ice crystals form.Official figures show that air traffic contributes around five per cent of greenhouse gases. Yet these estimates only account for CO emissions. They do not include the effect of contrails, which can persist for hours and even expand into cirrus clouds several miles wide. These clouds, which are most abundant over North America and Europe, trap heat within Earth’s atmosphere, so do they improve our climate or contribute to global warming Air traffic has been steadily increasing year-on-year, so, assuming the coronavirus effect is a temporary one, estimates suggest that the distance flown by passengers will double every  years, and that air traffic will quadruple by . Therefore, it is imperative to determine how the increase in clouds created by contrails might affect us.In a recent study*, scientists used a climate model to analyse the future impact of contrails on climate change, taking into account their predicted increase balanced against any likely changes in engine soot emissions.The results show a three-fold increase in contrail cirrus coverage by , despite a  per cent reduction in soot emissions due to improved fuel and engine efficiency. These predictions cover all major air traffic routes and are mostly due to increased air traffic volume, although a sht to flying at higher altitudes also contributes. The area with the greatest increase will be Eastern Asia, where the largest rise in air traffic is expected.This previously unaccounted for, non-CO, climate impact of air traffic is now reckoned to have a more damaging effect on climate change than all the CO emitted from aircraft engines.*Atmos. Chem. Phys., , -.

title: creative writing how to begin
story: Kenneth StevenUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe last few months have been a dficult and unsettling time. But it has also been a time of positive change and reflection, prompting people to be more creative. Writing, be it poetry, song writing or short stories, for example, has given many a way of making sense of this time, of sharing their feelings and looking after their mental health.For those who have found it dficult to know where to begin, Seil author Kenneth Steven offers this advice to help you start your creative writing journey.For me, there are two essential ingredients when it comes to setting out as a creative writer: time and space. By creative writing I mean poetry, short stories, novels and children’s writing: everything involving the use of the imagination.When someone claims they don’t have time to write, I don’t believe them as it’s a question of making time.PD James started writing when nursing a dying husband: he needed care all through the day. There was a part of the night when finally he went to sleep and she had the chance to put pen to paper, so that was what she did. If we are serious about wanting to write, we will make time.For many years I lived in Dunkeld, close to the entrance to the cathedral. When friends heard my address they would roll their eyes and say: ‘What a place to be. And you’re lucky enough to be a writer.’Except it wasn’t that easy. The truth is the modern world invaded even that idyllic corner of Scotland.First, there were thousands of pilgrim feet and voices. I was driven mad by not being able to find sufficient quiet. My former we watched a great deal of television. It was a tiny flat and the distant murmur of low voices maddened me because I couldn’t concentrate.It was she who suggested # probably to stop the grumbling # that I should have a cabin built in my mother’s garden in Aberfeldy, a place where I could hide away to write. After considering the idea for a few days, I realised she was right.When finally I sat down to start working in that simple shed among the trees, the words poured from the pen. I will never forget those first days. Poem after poem appeared as though by magic on the page. For me # and after many years of leading creative writing sessions, I would suggest for the vast majority of others too # finding real quiet makes all the dference.But it doesn’t have to be a hideaway in a garden it can be a living room or a bedroom or an attic – just at a time when others in the household are asleep or absent.There are few rules for creative writers, but one I have discovered is that we are all larks or owls. We’re either attracted to early morning or late evening.I have yet to meet anyone who has said they’re drawn to the mid-afternoon # what I term # hammock time, though that’s when I wrote in the Aberfeldy cabin. I’ve come to believe strongly you will use the time you are given. If that’s what you have, you will adapt to that rhythm.But I quickly came to realise in my cabin that I couldn’t simply turn on good writing like a tap. We go into our creative space weighed down by the modern world. We live lives beset by emails, phone calls and text messages. We are all expected to respond quickly.I think creative writers are generally poor when it comes to practice writing. The creative lives of visual artists, actors, singers and musicians are dominated by practice. Why should it be dferent for those from the writing community What do I mean by practice writing  Describing the view out of the window going back into memory to capture a moment as evocatively as possible imagining a dialogue between two characters. There’s no end to the possibilities. What practice writing provides is creative grounding. It brings us from being all over the place in our minds to give us creative focus.What this practice allows us to do is to start, then to pour ourselves into what I like to call deep writing. It creates a kind of doorway so the real writing can begin.Kenneth Steven is best-known as a poet. Sixteen of his collections have been published and he writes and presents poetry-related programmes for BBC Radio. He is also a Scottish novelist and children’s author. He’s written two handbooks on writing and led workshops and worked as writer in residence at home and abroad. www.kennethsteven
